subject: Re: [junit] Using JUnit Inside Application Server?
msgSnippet: Thanks David, That was what I was trying to say /and/ I think decoupling your code from EJB specifics and JNDI lookups and EJB-lifecycle events is a good idea.
messageBody:
Thanks David,
That was what I was trying to say /and/ I think decoupling your code from
EJB specifics and JNDI lookups and EJB-lifecycle events is a good idea. An
EJB container is an execution environment and business logic should not
depend on where it is executing. A combination of JUnit-tests without cactus
and systemtests (executed as a client against the application deployed in a
container works well in our project). The latter is run with our homecooked
acceptance testing framework and the former with junit. This is possible
because our EJB:s are merely shells contining our services that are
implemented as pojos and tested outside the EJB.

It works well for us. Of course there are different ways to skin a cat :)

On 11/3/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Just to clarify, on projects like this, I usually have two levels of
> tests:
> user tests that verify that the end user sees what she expects (running in
> the container, even through the browser), and developer tests that verify
> that my classes work as I expect. For user tests, it's essential to have
> all the components in place. For developer tests, it's counter-productive:
> I want to understand what my code does independently of what services are
> provided by third-party containers or servers, and I also want to run
> developer tests often and fast.
>
> I think this is the same thing Vishal is saying below, but I wanted a
> chance
> to rephrase it a little. Thanks,
>
> David Saff
>
>
> On 11/2/06, Vishal Vishnoi <vvishnoi@... <vvishnoi%40bea.com>> wrote:
> >
> > Use Cactus
> > (http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/writing/howto_testcase.html). It's
> > very easy to package you test and run them on server side. They also
> > have documentation on how to test EJB or any regular JUnit test in the
> > container.
> >
> > For higher level testing (i.e testing like a customer), if you need to
> > verify something in container, then verify it in container. Don't try to
> > run it outside, otherwise the whole purpose of testing is lost.
> >
> > --Vishal
> >
> > lenniedg2000 wrote:
> >
> > > Hi,
> > >
> > > I'm using Eclipse 3.2, Orion application server, J2EE 5.0, Oracle
> > > database.
> > >
> > > I've written a jUnit test but it doesn't run since it doesn't run
> > > within the application server "container" and so can't find the
> > > database data-sources that I've setup.
> > >
> > > How can I run jUnit unit tests inside an application server
> "container"?
> > >
> > > Kind Regards,
> > >
> > > Lennie De Villiers
